Award.AwardTitle: II-EN: Compute Infrastructure for Large-Scale Data Analytics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Computing Research Infrastructure project aims to enhance Worcester Polytechnic Institute's (WPI) high-performance infrastructure to support its ongoing research and education centered around big data analytics over scalable infrastructure. The enhanced compute clustering will provide a scalable infrastructure to support large-scale data analytics research along a number of important directions, including (1) a full-fledged software platform for seamlessly supporting large-scale continuous and recurring workloads with stream-window-centric query processing, (2) scalable annotation and provenance management for natively supporting annotations as first-class citizen over big data and exploiting their semantics in query processing and quality inference, (3) complex event analytics that combines complex event processing with OLAP techniques for efficient multi-dimensional event pattern detection in high-speed large-volume data, and (4) multi-model-driven analytics system on high-velocity data streams with visual exploration of the derived models and patterns. The projects collectively address key research challenges related to the analysis of large volume, high velocity, and wide variety of data.

The infrastructure is expected to significantly enhance the integration of research and education at both the undergraduate and graduate levels at WPI, including in particular, WPI's project-oriented undergraduate curriculum, which requires each undergraduate to complete a year-long research project. The infrastructure will also benefit a diverse group of researchers at WPI in different departments -- as is the case with the current compute cluster -- to conduct their data-intensive research. Broad dissemination of results of research enabled by the infrastructure including research publications, open-source software, and educational materials are expected to benefit the scientific community at large.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three major outcomes from the project are highlighted below:

1) The PIs have successfully deployed the new cluster and it is currently working with full capacity. It has been integrated with the existing old cluster, such that both of them can serve different purposes. The old cluster is for testing, debugging, and initial development, while the new cluster is for large-scale experiments and educational activities.

2) In terms of intellectual merit, the new computer cluster is supporting several of the PIs' research projects and producing top-tier publications since 2014 including papers in SIGMOD, VLDB, ICDE, VLDBJ, KDD, EDBT, CIKM,  and TKDE. These projects cover a wide spectrum of emerging research areas including scientific data management, big data query processing and analytics, complex event processing, data curation and annotation management,  stream processing, and real-time and interactive mining techniques.

3) The computer cluster is also supporting our educational mission in the context of big data. In particular, it is currently used in several of our courses including CS585 (Big Data Management) and CS586 (Big Data Analytics).

4) In terms of outreach and visibility, the computer cluster is being utilized by students in projects related with industrial partners, such as,  Graduate Qualifying projects for the interdisciplinary Data Science program and senior project work for the Computer Science program conducted under sponsorship by a company. Furthermore, underrepresented minority undergraduate students  from our Data Science REU summer site have utilized this NSF supported equipment for their projects. This thus trains the future generation in critical cloud computing skills and technologies.

 


Last Modified: 09/27/2016
Modified by: Mohamed Y Eltabakh
